newsitem.title: MALAYSIA: Malaysia in big property development deal.
newsitem.headline: Malaysia in big property development deal.

text.p: The Malaysian government on Tuesday signed an agreement with developers to build a 5-10 billion-ringgit ($2.5-$4 billion) commercial project in Kuala Lumpur that will be more than a mile long.
The 2.4-km (1.4-mile) long GigaWorld complex is part of the 12-km (seven-mile) KL LinearCity project that is to be built over and along the Klang River running through Kuala Lumpur.
The 10-storey, tube-like GigaWorld is to be built on stilts over the river. It will be construct in stages over the next 20-25 years.
The Malaysian government said it would be the world's longest building.
The agreements were signed between KL LinearCity Sdn Bhd and the Malaysian government, state property firm Syarikat Tanah dan Harta Sdn Bhd and the Kuala Lumpur City Council.
Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad, a strong backer of the project, witnessed the signing ceremony.

Under the agreements, the developers received a 99-year lease on 216.5 acres of government-owned river land for 611 million ringgit. A massive clean-up of the murky Klang River is also part of the deal, the developers said.
KL LinearCity is led by Chairman Kamarudin Jaffar, an advisor to Deputy Prime Minister and Finance Minister Anwar Ibrahim.

His board of directors includes Berjaya Group chairman Vincent Tan and Wan Adli Wan Ibrahim, executive chairman of Transwater Corp Bhd, which has a privatisation contract to run the nation's sewerage treatment systems.
KL LinearCity has paid-up capital of 50 million ringgit and authorised capital of 300 million ringgit.
In a statemment at the ceremony, KL LinearCity said the project was expected to be financed by a mix of shareholders' equity and commercial debt financing.
The company said it was preparing to secure a listing on the Kuala Lumpur Stock Exchange under new rules introduced last year allowing new infrastructure projects to be publicly traded.

The government also signed an agreement awarding a 2.2 billion-ringgit contract to KL PRT Sdn Bhd to build a light rail system called the People-mover Rapid Transit system, which will partly run alongside the project.
